questions.answer_description:
In AWS CloudFormation, if you want to map an Amazon Elastic Block Store to an Amazon EC2 instance, you reference the logical IDs to associate the block stores with the instance.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/concept-resources.html

choices.B: you reference the physical IDs of the instance along with the resource type
choices.C: you reference the instance IDs of the block store along with the resource properties
choices.D: you reference the physical IDs of both the block stores and the instance
choices.A: you reference the logical IDs to associate the block stores with the instance

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The correct answer is:

A. you reference the logical IDs to associate the block stores with the instance.

In CloudFormation, to map an Amazon Elastic Block Store (EBS) to an Amazon EC2 instance, you reference the logical IDs of the resources. Logical IDs are defined within the CloudFormation template and are used to associate resources with each other. By referencing the logical IDs, you can specify the relationship between the EC2 instance and the EBS volumes that should be attached to it.

Option B is incorrect because physical IDs are not used in CloudFormation to associate resources.

Option C is incorrect because instance IDs are not used to reference block stores in CloudFormation.

Option D is incorrect because referencing the physical IDs of both the block stores and the instance is not the standard practice in CloudFormation for mapping resources.
Agree its A. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/resources-section-structure.html

questions.question_text:
An organization hosts an app on EC2 instances which multiple developers need access to in order to perform updates.
The organization plans to implement some security best practices related to instance access.
Which one of the following recommendations will not help improve its security in this way?
questions.answer_description:
Since AWS is a public cloud any application hosted on EC2 is prone to hacker attacks. It becomes extremely important for a user to setup a proper security mechanism on the EC2 instances. A few of the security measures are listed below:
✑ Always keep the OS updated with the latest patch
✑ Always create separate users with in OS if they need to connect with the EC2 instances, create their keys and disable their password
✑ Create a procedure using which the admin can revoke the access of the user when the business work on the EC2 instance is completed. . Lock down unnecessary ports
✑ Audit any proprietary applications that the user may be running on the EC2 instance. Provide temporary escalated privileges, such as sudo for users who need to perform occasional privileged tasks
IAM is useful when users are required to work with AWS resources and actions, such as launching an instance. It is not useful in this case because it does not manage who can connect via RDP or SSH with an instance.
Reference:
http://aws.amazon.com/articles/1233/

choices.C: Create a procedure to revoke the access rights of the individual user when they are not required to connect to EC2 instance anymore for the purpose of application configuration.
choices.B: Create an IAM policy allowing only IAM users to connect to the EC2 instances with their own SSH key.
choices.A: Disable the password based login for all the users. All the users should use their own keys to connect with the instance securely.
choices.D: Apply the latest patch of OS and always keep it updated.

choices.A: It is not possible to have more than one security group assigned to a single instance
choices.D: It allows inbound traffic on port 22 for IP 10.10.10.1 and for everyone else on port 80
choices.C: It allows inbound traffic for everyone on both ports 22 and 80
choices.B: It is not possible to create the security group with conflicting rules. AWS will reject the request

questions.answer_description:
A user can attach more than one security group to a single EC2 instance. In this case, the rules from each security group are effectively aggregated to create one set of rules. AWS uses this set of rules to determine whether to allow access or not. Thus, here the rule for port 22 with IP 10.10.10.1/32 will merge with IP
0.0.0.0/0 and open ports 22 and 80 for all.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/using-network-security.html

discussion.content: C. It allows inbound traffic for everyone on both ports 22 and 80
clearly C
C also, Security group rules are always permissive; you can't create rules that deny access.

C is the right answer.
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ec2-security-groups.html
If there is more than one rule for a specific port, we apply the most permissive rule. For example, if you have a rule that allows access to TCP port 22 (SSH) from IP address 203.0.113.1 and another rule that allows access to TCP port 22 from everyone, everyone has access to TCP port 22.
Yes D is correct: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/ec2-security-groups.html

D.

If there is more than one rule for a SPECIFIC PORT, we apply the most permissive rule. For example, if you have a rule that allows access to TCP port 22 (SSH) from IP address 203.0.113.1 and another rule that allows access to TCP port 22 from everyone, everyone has access to TCP port 22.

The rule on port 22 and the other on 80 should remain two separate rules in the merged rules set.

choices.C: Create a Route 53 Failover Routing Policy and assign each resource record set a unique identifier and a relative weight.

questions.answer_description:
It is best to use the latency routing policy when you have resources in multiple Amazon EC2 data centers that perform the same function and you want Amazon
Route 53 to respond to DNS queries with the resources that provide the best latency. You could also use the failover routing policy (for public hosted zones only) when you want to configure an active-passive failover, in which one resource takes all traffic when it's available and the other resource takes all traffic when the first resource isn't available.
Reference:
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/Route53/latest/DeveloperGuide/routing-policy.html#routing-policy-latency
